main_text:
Plato’s shorter ethical works show Socrates at work on topics
related to virtue, which he believes we should seek for the sake of
the soul as we should seek health for the body. Works in this group
shows stylistic as well as philosophic affinities and are generally
considered to have been written early in Plato’s career. The
dialogues in this group are our main source for the philosophical
style and teaching of the Platonic Socrates, who is thought by some
scholars to be to a reasonable approximation of the historical figure.
In this article, “Socrates” always refers to the Platonic
figure in the works under discussion here. He is distinct from the
Socrates of Plato’s middle works in that he treats the soul as a
unity, whereas the Socrates of Republic 2–10 and other
middle dialogues treats it as divided into two or three parts. 

Sections 2 through 9 concern philosophical themes that are common to
the works under discussion. Section 10 deals with the intellectual
world that Plato uses as a backdrop for these dialogues. Sections 11
to 20 deal with the individual dialogues of the group. The views of
this Socrates are hard to make out with certainty because he often
speaks in questions, and when he makes statemens they may be strategic
elements in a refutaion and not his true views. Scholars therefore
have been engaged in many controversies about his views. For details
on these, see companion volumes such as Rappe, and Kamtekar (2005),
Morrison (2011), Bussanich and Smith (2013), and Jones and Smith
(2023).
